conclusion: Analyze the problem using geometric optics to determine where a point light source must be positioned inside a glass sphere to ensure all emitted light can exit the sphere.
Glass sphere with radius R and refractive index n, center labeled O, internal point light source S emits light in all directions.
Determine the condition on the position of S to ensure all light rays can exit the sphere.
Light can undergo total internal reflection if the angle of incidence exceeds the critical angle when passing from glass to air.
Critical angle θc is given by sin θc = 1/n, where n is the refractive index of glass.
Ray originating from S must strike the sphere's surface at an angle of incidence less than the critical angle to exit the sphere.
Most restrictive case occurs for rays with the largest angle of incidence at the sphere surface.
S is at some distance d from the center O, ray from S makes an angle θ with the radial line at the point of incidence P.
Angle of incidence θ is the angle between the ray and the normal (radius) at P, normal at P is along the radius OP.
Maximum angle of incidence occurs when the ray is tangent to a circle centered at O with radius d.
Maximum angle of incidence θmax can be calculated using the law of sines in triangle OPS: sin θmax = d/R.
To ensure all rays exit the sphere, maximum angle must be less than the critical angle: d/R < 1/n.
Point source must be positioned such that its distance d from the center O satisfies d < R/n.
